subject: Re: [junit] Should I ever catch unwanted Exceptions inside my tests?

messageBody:
Espen Ã˜. Pedersen wrote:

>What actually is good practice:
>
>
>Keep the test methods clean and let the testXXX method throw the
>Exception to JUnit and let junit report an error.
>(unless you are testing expected Exceptions of course)
>
>
>Or Catch the Exception inside the test and handle it somehow?
>
>
>

The way others and myself look at this is: what would you do with the
caught exceptions?

If its a case of failing the test, then its simply easier (most of the
time) to not catch the exception in the first place.

eg:

public void testSomethingThatShouldWork() throws Exception {
// test something that should work, and don't worry about any
exceptions is MAY raise.
}


Or if its a case of the test is testing that a particular exception is
expected to be thrown, then you would obviously need to catch it.

eg

public void testMySpecialExceptionThrown() throws Exception {
try{
MyObject = new MyObject();
fail("MySepcialException not thrown as expected!");
} catch(MySpecialException mse) {
// Only want to catch MySpecialExceptions, other exceptions should
fail this test!
}

}
